results:
The search results provide excellent information connecting Louise Brown's birth in 1978 as the first IVF baby to Aldous Huxley's earlier predictions in "Brave New World." Here's what the search revealed:

## Louise Brown and the First IVF Baby (1978)

Louise Joy Brown (born 25 July 1978) is an English woman noted as the first human born following conception by in vitro fertilisation (IVF).(no content)At 11.47 PM on July 25th 1978, Louise Brown was delivered by an elective caesarean section at Oldham hospital by the registrar John Webster at gestational age of 38 weeks and 5 days due to coincidence of maternal pre-eclampsia.

## Huxley's Prescient Prediction in "Brave New World" (1932)

The search results reveal a fascinating connection between Louise Brown's birth and earlier science fiction predictions. In 1932, Aldous Huxley described the technique of IVF in his science fiction novel "Brave New World". This novel was published 46 years before Louise Brown's actual birth.

## Contemporary Reactions and Comparisons

When Louise Brown was born, many people immediately drew connections to Huxley's novel. Newspapers and readers made regular comparisons to Aldous Huxley's 1934 novel Brave New World, in which natural sexual reproduction is banned and humans are grown in labs through a process similar to what happened before the embryo was placed inside Lesley's womb.(no content)It also touched off fevered speculation and ethical debate over wonders to come: the possibilities of surrogate mothers, the creation of superbeings and an Aldous Huxley vision of embryos nurtured to birth in artificial wombs.

## The Medical Breakthrough

Her birth, following a procedure pioneered in Britain, has been lauded among "the most remarkable medical breakthroughs of the 20th century". The procedure was developed by Patrick Steptoe, Robert Edwards, and Jean Purdy.(no content)Edwards was awarded the 2010 Nobel Prize in Medicine for this work.

## Legacy and Impact

Since then, IVF has become a common procedure with a record of more than 5 million births worldwide. More recent data shows that over 12 million babies have been born through IVF and other Assisted Reproductive Technologies (ARTs), making parenthood possible for millions worldwide, including same-sex couples and single individuals.

The connection between Huxley's 1932 fictional prediction and the 1978 reality of Louise Brown's birth demonstrates how science fiction can sometimes anticipate real scientific advances, though the actual implementation of IVF was far more benevolent than Huxley's dystopian vision suggested.
